title: Limiting the thread stack for parallel threads test
body:
## Description
Previously, the RTOS threads test would conditionally change the thread stack size for all test cases based on the target. Now, it uses the default stack size for all targets when threads are created serially, and uses a 512 byte stack for the threads that are created in parallel.

Also, this should remove the last failing test case on the ARCH_PRO platform :)


## Status
**READY**


## Migrations
If this PR changes any APIs or behaviors, give a short description of what *API users* should do when this PR is merged.

NO


## Todos
- [x] Tests

## Notes to Reviewers
Requesting reviews by @c1728p9 and @geky since they are familiar with all things RTOS and stack-sizey (yes that's a technical term)

Also requesting a review by @pan- as this may affect some of the BLE platforms/constrained mbeds.

title: Removing default toolchain paths
body:
## Description
This change was spurred by a confusing error. I attempted to compile for the RZ_A1H (a Cortex-A device), and I had the standalone ARM compiler in my system path, which supports Cortex-A. However, the default path for the ARM compiler in settings.py uses a Keil installation, which only supports Cortex-M. It found my Keil installation and used that instead, **causing a compiler error**. This change proposes to remove this default behavior and instead **requires the user to explicitly set the intended compiler path**, either by a settings file, mbed CLI, environment variables, or by placing the compiler in your PATH.


## Status
**READY**


## Migrations
**YES**

This will now require that a user sets the compiler paths via mbed CLI, environment variables, settings files, or by placing them in the system PATH.

I realize this could be a breaking change for some developers, so perhaps we should wait a release before doing this? We could detect that the default path in settings.py is being used and warn the users to set the compiler path explicitly. **Open to suggestions here!**

## Todos
- [ ] Tests
- [ ] Documentation


## Notes to Maintainers
I requested a lot of reviewers on this PR since this is changing some legacy behavior that we've had for quite some time now. It'd be good to get input from everyone since this may affect many different parts of the mbed ecosystem.

title: Stm32f7 ethernet fix for IAR issue #3387
body:
## Description
See the detailed explanation of the issue here
A few sentences describing the overall goals of the pull request's commits.
https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/issues/3387
The ethernet buffers are located in the SRAM1 memory that has data cache enable.
Extract from the mbed.map:
```
DMARxDscrTab            0x20012aa4    0x80  Data  Gb  stm32f7_emac.o [8]
DMATxDscrTab            0x20012b24    0x80  Data  Gb  stm32f7_emac.o [8]
Rx_Buff                 0x20012ba4  0x17d0  Data  Gb  stm32f7_emac.o [8]
Tx_Buff                 0x20014374  0x17d0  Data  Gb  stm32f7_emac.o [8]
```
The DMA descriptors are written by the CPU, and kept in cache.
The Ethernet IP is then reading the DMA descriptor in the SRAM1 memory, that does not contains the requested information (still in cache)
You can see in the Reference Manual of STM32F746 that we set an address for the DMA descriptor to the ETH registers, and that the IP is reading this address directly.
http://www.st.com/resource/en/reference_manual/dm00124865.pdf page 1586 for ETH_DMATDLAR

It used to work before because those buffers' allocation was hard coded on 0x2000xxxx
This memory is the DTCM ram, 0 wait state, no cache. It can remain like this, but it is not the best performance choice (because when Ethernet is accessing the datas, the CPU is blocked).

The best choice is then to use SRAM1 and disable the data cache. The SRAM1 and SRAM2 are really fast and the system performance should not suffer from this choice.

## Status
READY

## Todos
I was able to fix features-feature_lwip-tests-mbedmicro-net-udp_echo_client test with this bug fix.
@geky or someone else, could you check that it also solves the issue #3387 ?


## Steps to test or reproduce
before this PR : 
mbed test -m NUCLEO_F746ZG -t IAR -n features-feature_lwip-tests-mbedmicro-net-udp_echo_client was failing
now  it works

title: [RZ/A1H]Fix TTB setting of RO_DATA area
body:
I modified the TTB setting of RO_DATA area.
The current setting of this area is "not executable".
Therefore, when trying to execute a program placed in this area, a prefetch abort will occur.
So I changed from "Sect_Normal_RO" to "Sect_Normal_Cod".

title: [STM32] CAN write() return value
body:
### Description
- Type: Bug
- Related issue: #3463
- Priority: Major

According to the [CAN.h](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/drivers/CAN.h#L130-L131) header file the `write()` method is only supposed to return `1` if send was successful. All of the STM32 implementations in `can_api.c` are hard coded to `return 1;`.

- [STM32F0](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F0/can_api.c#L229)
- [STM32F1](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F1/can_api.c#L232)
- [STM32F2](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F2/can_api.c#L242)
- [STM32F3](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F3/can_api.c#L232)
- [STM32F4](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F4/can_api.c#L245)
- [STM32F7](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F7/can_api.c#L245)
- [STM32L4](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F0/can_api.c#L232)

The NXP targets implement this correctly, [can_api.c](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_NXP/TARGET_LPC176X/can_api.c#L356-L400)

---------------------------------------------------------------
## Bug

**Target**
STM32

**Expected behavior**
Only return `1` if write was successful.

**Actual behavior**
Returns `1` regardless if write was successful.

**Steps to reproduce**
```c
if (can1.write(CANMessage(1337, &data, sizeof(data)))
{
    // This will always print
    printf("tx\n");
}
```

title: [STM32] CAN read() return value
body:
### Description
- Type: Bug
- Priority: Major

According to the [CAN.h](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/drivers/CAN.h#L141-L142) header file the `read()` method is only supposed to return `1` if data was read. All of the STM32 implementations in `can_api.c` are hard coded to `return 1;`.

- [STM32F0](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F0/can_api.c#L270)
- [STM32F1](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F1/can_api.c#L273)
- [STM32F2](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F2/can_api.c#L283)
- [STM32F3](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F3/can_api.c#L273)
- [STM32F4](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F4/can_api.c#L286)
- [STM32F7](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F7/can_api.c#L286)
- [STM32L4](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_STM/TARGET_STM32F0/can_api.c#L270)

The NXP targets implement this correctly, [can_api.c](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/targets/TARGET_NXP/TARGET_LPC176X/can_api.c#L421-L424)

---------------------------------------------------------------
## Bug

**Target**
STM32

**Expected behavior**
Only return `1` if **new** data was read.

**Actual behavior**
Returns `1` regardless if data was received or not. If a message has previously been received then this will be returned again.

**Steps to reproduce**
```c
CANMessage msg;
while(true)
{
    if (can1.read(msg))
    {
        // This will always print
        printf("rx -id: %i, data: %x\n", msg.id, *msg.data);
    }
}
```

title: [ONME-2844] Avoid option level collisions
body:
To allow a network stack to support both NSAPI and its own options, try to make
sure the NSAPI levels don't collide with level numbers likely to be used by
network stacks.

Distinguish between socket and stack options, and tighten up documentation. Add
IP MRU stack options as an example (implementation not immediately planned for
any stack, but could be useful).

title: [ONME-2844] Supporting non-blocking connect()
body:
A few new error codes are added to nsapi_error_t and
support for non-blocking socket connect is added.
Nanostack's connect call will be non-blocking.
Whereas LWIP connect call is currently blocking, and it could be changed now
to be non-blocking.

title: Mbed build broken for TARGET UBLOX EVK ODIN W2 using GCC ARM toolchain
body:
Description

Hi,

I have been trying to build mbed os 5 for UBLOX_EVK_ODIN_W2 using Mbed native tools i.e build.py present under mbed-os/tools folder but I am facing the issue while the compiler tries to build wifi_emac_api.py . 
I have used the following command to build:

**>python build.py -m UBLOX_EVK_ODIN_W2 -t GCC_ARM**

body:
Sarah Marsh reported this issue as follows:



From: Sarah Marsh 
Sent: 13 December 2016 23:48
To: Simon Hughes; Marcus Chang
Subject: Enabling config store in SRAM for cloud client

Hello Simon and Marcus,

I have been tasked with getting a cellular device to connect to mbed cloud. It requires configuration store, but I was told there is a way to use config store in SRAM rather than nonvolatile memory for targets that have not implemented a storage class. Marcus suggested using these macros https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/features/storage/FEATURE_STORAGE/cfstore/source/cfstore_config.h#L44-L57 for such a target. Using these and turning on the "STORAGE" feature for my target in targets.json, compilation fails at the reference to cfstore_svm_storage_drv
here:
https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/754bd243010732d273f5ec931f53945edc2f5405/features/storage/FEATURE_STORAGE/cfstore/source/cfstore_svm.cpp#L63

The macros enable definition of that variable here:
https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/blob/master/features/storage/FEATURE_STORAGE/cfstore/source/cfstore_svm.cpp#L40-L42. 
Obviously, that is a storage implementation unique to K64F. Should that variable be defined in an else clause for targets without a storage class? Or is there another step I need to take? 

Marcus, sorry for the duplicate information and yet another email, but I wanted to put the information in one place.

Thanks for your time,
Sarah Marsh

title: Fix ci shield eeprom test

With ci test shiled tests, a few issues were faced and needed to be solved 
- the reference I2C test makes a mixed usage for unitary MBED APIs (start / stop / send & read bytes) and more advanced read and write APIs which autonomously manage start and stop. The code needed update to cope with this API use.
- also the eeprom driver checks if eeprom is ready by sending data of length = 0, the STM32 HAL provides a dedicated API for such case which we're using now

This allows to have the I2C eeprom test to pass on F1, F2, F4 and L1 families.

This is PR contains a clean-up of the init phases which was not seen before but has been seen while moving F1 family to the common I2C code as well. So this PR is a pre-requisite to later introduction of F1 to common code (and F1 asynch I2C support at the same time)

title: Change slave address in I2C master slave asynch test
body: 0x90 is I2C slave device address which is used on by temperature sensor (like TMP102 temperature sensor, also on ci test shiled). So to avoid conflicts on a board where the sensor is used and we also want to test master / slave communication, I propose to change the default salve address to another one (if 0x80 is not suitable, feel free to propose another one)

title: Fix stm i2c slave
body:
Having a master I2C and a slave I2C communicating together on the same device is maybe not a real use case, but this PR allows to pass "master slave asynch" tests at higher frequencies than the default 100kHz for boards like NUCLEO_L152RE (32MHz) and NUCLEO_F042K6  (48MHz)

The 2nd commit restores the slave address in error cases, when no devices is found for instance or when bus is locked in a busy state.

## Status
**READY**

TESTED OK with  MBED_A29: i2c_master_slave_asynch.

title: TimeStamp starts from 0 after microcontroller wakeup from Standby mode
body:
Note: This is just a template, so feel free to use/remove the unnecessary things

### Description
- Type: Bug | Enhancement | Question


I am using STM32l06 microcntroller's custom board and when microcontroller wakesup from stand by mode, according to datasheet, it should not loose time stamp, but for me it always start from 0. The reason I found is that in rtc_api.c file  there was a flag that  gets cleared every time after controller comes out of standby mode, and in mbed library, the code is written to check if that flag is cleared then start time stamp from 0 again, now I dont know if it is right approach or not, but in mbed file i made change, i checked if rtc_read gives a value greater than some significant value, then i return 1, so time doesnt start from 0 again. So the problem is fixed, but I had to make changes in mbed file,. seems like mbed need to update that file.

title: STM32F4 - FIX to add the update of hdma->State variable
body:
## Description
This is a fix to add the update of hdma->State variable as it was done in a previous version of HAL driver.

This change is required as we need to figure out which kind of event has triggered the IRQ (for example to know if it was a TX/RX buffer half-complete or a full-complete event) in order to call the right callback (specified by the mbed application programmer) with the right parameters.

With the old HAL DMA API we could figure this easily out by first calling HAL_DMA_IRQHandler() and then analyzing the states of the DMA stream (by using HAL_DMA_GetState()).

With the new HAL DMA API this approach does not work anymore. The state is not updated in the HAL_DMA_IRQHandler(), the state machine will stay in a Busy State until we abort the transfer. These states information have been removed.

## Status
READY

## Migrations
NO

CC @betzw

title: STM32L0 : map ST HAL assert into MBED assert
body:
## Description
ST HAL assert is mapped onto MBED HAL assert, and can now be enabled easily.

Note for all STM32 targets:
- ST asserts are used to check each parameters in ST HAL function call
- They are not compiled by default, you have to define USE_FULL_ASSERT to enable them

## Test

OS2 and OS5 tests done.

Few updates have been needed to match ST HAL API.

## Status
READY

title: lwip - Fixed error codes for failed TCP connect
body:
Some error codes in TCP connect were being remapped incorrectly
```
condition               posix error     mbed error
good host, closed port  ECONNREFUSED    NSAPI_ERROR_NO_CONNECTION
bad host                EHOSTUNREACH    NSAPI_ERROR_NO_CONNECTION
bad network             ENETUNREACH     NSAPI_ERROR_NO_CONNECTION
```

Thanks to @infinnovation for finding this, verified with their test program in https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/issues/3246

cc @infinnovation, @c1728p9 
should resolve https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/issues/3246

title: nsapi - Fixed open/close issue in Socket
body:
During open, the socket checked the internal stack variable, assuming it would alway be null on a socket not connected to the network. However, when a socket is closed, the stack variable was not updated, causing the socket to incorrectly return a parameter error if reopened.

The simple fix was to set the stack to null on close. A non-null stack is a predicate for a non-null socket variable, so no additional checks are needed in socket functions.

Required for https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/pull/3265

title: nrf52 - UARTE not available
body:
### Description
- Type: Question
- Priority: Major

## Question

nrf52 has 2 UART peripherals (UART and UARTE). mbed provides HAL implementation for UART only, therefore in the peripheral map theres only one UART. This UART however is used as stdio. Thus a user does not have any free uart available. For instance, if there's serial wifi shield, it can't be used out of the box.

I checked the reference manual, looks to me there's UARTE available. That could be used by an application.

Are there any limitations ?

@nvlsianpu

title: C027 - Thread example not working
body:
### Description
- Type: Bug
---------------------------------------------------------------
## Bug

**Target**
C027

**Toolchain:**
mbed online compiler

-----------------------------------------------------------------

## Question

**How to start running a thread with Thread::start() ?**

The example in the docs for the thread (from the Thread.h) is not working at all.
Compiled on the mbed online compiler with the newest version of mbed-os imported directly from github.

`#include "mbed.h"`
`#include "rtos.h"`

`Thread thread;`
`DigitalOut led1(LED1);`
`volatile bool running = true;`

`// Blink function toggles the led in a long running loop`
`void blink(DigitalOut *led) {`
`    while (running) {`
`        *led = !*led;`
`        Thread::wait(1000);`
`    }`
`}`
`// Spawns a thread to run blink for 5 seconds`
`int main() {`
`     thread.start(led1, blink);`
`     Thread::wait(5000);`
`     running = false;`
`     thread.join();`
`}`

**Compiler error number:** 304
**Compiler error description:** No instance of overloaded function "rtos::Thread::start" matches the argument list "thread.start(led1, blink);"

title: Enable broadcast on UDPSocket on LPC1768
body:
## Description
- Type: Question
- Priority: Blocker


## Question

**How to enable broadcast option on a UDPSocket?**

I'm struggling to find an answer to this question.

I managed to find an old solution `sock.set_broadcasting();` in some example but this method is not defined anymore in mbed-os 5.2. This method is still defined in `features/unsupported/net/lwip/Socket/UDPSocket.cpp` thought.
I tried to have a look at lwip feature but seems to rely on nsapi a lot and nsapi doesn't define the `SO_BROADCAST` socket option.

Did anyone faced a similar problem ? Is there a workaround ?

Best regards,
Ben

title: Release candidate for mbed-os-5.3.0-rc3
ISR register never re-evaluated in HAL_DMA_PollForTransfer for STM32F4
body:
## Description
The ISR register is never re-evaluated in HAL_DMA_PollForTransfer for STM32F4.
This will cause the function to unnecessarily wait for timeout in some circumstances.
Putting 'tmpisr = regs->ISR;' at the end of the while loop solves it for the ODIN driver.

## Status
**READY**

## Migrations
NO

## Related PRs
https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/issues/3272

## Todos
Review by @LMESTM 

## Deploy notes
None

## Steps to test or reproduce
This has been reproduced with the private repo of the u-blox ODIN-drivers and the fix can therefore only be verified by u-blox for the UBLOX_EVK_ODIN_W2 target. The current ODIN-W2 driver binary for mbed-os v5.3.0 has a workaround therefore it's not affected.
- Get ublox ODIN drivers branch alar_sdio_optimizations
- Get mbed-os commit 9d8ec61
- Run WiFi and BT tests. WiFi will timeout because initialization is too slow(~15 sec)
The tests below have been run with the fix in the PR and without the workaround.
[test_report_arm.txt](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/files/639118/test_report_arm.txt)
[test_report_gcc.txt](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/files/639120/test_report_gcc.txt)
[test_report_iar.txt](https://github.com/ARMmbed/mbed-os/files/639119/test_report_iar.txt)
